questions.text: What should be the sequence of events during collection of blood sample?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask the patient his name verify from file > collect blood > Label the sample at bedside

options.label: B
options.text: Look at the file > Collect sample > Label the sample at bedside

options.label: C
options.text: Pre label the sample vials > Check the file patient details > Collect sample

options.label: D
options.text: Collect sample > Confirm name from file > Label the sample vial

questions.correct_answer: A. Ask the patient his name verify from file > collect blood > Label the sample at bedside

Causes of a dry tap when performing a bone marrow aspiration may be expected in:
In a patient with alpha thalassemia trait, all of the following features are typically observed except:

options.label: C
options.text: Target cells on the peripheral smear

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Answers:
  • • B. Mild microcytic hypochromic anemia: This is a typical feature of thalassemia trait. The reduced synthesis of normal hemoglobin in thalassemia leads to microcytosis (smaller red blood cells) and hypochromia (paler red blood cells).
  • • C. Target cells on the peripheral smear: Target cells (cells that resemble a "bull's-eye" due to abnormal hemoglobin distribution) are commonly seen in the peripheral blood smear of patients with thalassemia trait. They are a result of the altered hemoglobin production and red blood cell membrane abnormalities.
  • • D. Disproportionately elevated RBC count: In thalassemia trait, the body compensates for the low hemoglobin by increasing red blood cell production, leading to a disproportionately elevated RBC count relative to the degree of anemia. This is a characteristic feature of thalassemia trait.

questions.text: A 30-years-old male with long-standing history of diarrhea, has macrocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies in RBC, target cells and small shrunken spleen. The most likely diagnosis is:
Iron deficiency may result in the misdiagnosis of:

A child with a known diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis develops “slapped cheek” appearance as well as profound anemia. Reticulocyte response to the anemia is inadequate. A bone marrow examination is most likely to demonstrate:

options.label: A
options.text: Hypocellular marrow with reduction of all cell lines

options.label: B
options.text: Erythroid hyperplasia as a response to acute hemolysis

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced erythropoiesis with giant erythroblasts and intranuclear inclusions

options.label: D
options.text: “Owl eye” appearance, due to CMV infection in erythroid precursors

questions.correct_answer: C. Reduced erythropoiesis with giant erythroblasts and intranuclear inclusions

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) are true except:

The stain used for the demonstration of reticulocyte is-
Microspherocytosis in peripheral blood smear are seen in-
Which of the following is an effective marker for erythroid precursors?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Answers:
  • • A. CD34: CD34 is a stem cell marker found on hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells, including those that give rise to erythroid lineage cells. However, CD34 is not specific to erythroid precursors and is present on a broader range of hematopoietic progenitors, making it less useful for specifically identifying erythroid precursors compared to CD71.
  • • C. CD41: CD41 is a marker for platelet progenitors and megakaryocytes. It is expressed on cells in the platelet lineage and is not relevant for identifying erythroid precursors.
  • • D. CD61: CD61 is another platelet marker, also known as the integrin β3 subunit. It is expressed on megakaryocytes and platelets, not on erythroid precursors, making it irrelevant in the context of erythropoiesis.
